discussion.content: A loopback adapter is required if you are installing on a non-networked computer to connect the computer to a network after the installation. When you install a loopback adapter, the loopback adapter assigns a local IP address for your computer.
loop back adapters are used to test T1 lines
A is the best answer, because the rest are the wrong answer.

comments.content: The question is asking for 'to verify the configuration of the router' which only leaves us with A.

questions.question_text: A technician is diagnosing an issue with a new T1 connection. The router is configured, the cable is connected, but the T1 is down. To verify the configuration of the router, which of the following tools should the technician use?

discussion.content: wouldn't a logical next step be to use netstat to confirm that ports 67/68 are open and responding, rather than jump right to a packet sniffer?

comments.content:
Technician can ping the DHCP server meaning its connected to the network, however it is not handing IP addresses as expected. 

Packet sniffers work by examining streams of data packets that flow between computers on a network as well as between networked computers and the larger Internet.

From these packets the technician can better diagnose the problem.

discussion.content: If this is the correct answer could somebody explain?

comments.content: I think it means they can ping so ICMP is working, next then would be to see what is happening via traffic on the DHCP ports if there are any clues as to why no talky talky at DHCP.

questions.question_text: A technician has been asked to diagnose problems with DHCP addressing on a VLAN. The DHCP server responds to pings from the technician's machine. Which of the following should the technician use to help diagnose the problem?

discussion.content:
clustering A technology that enables two or more computers to act as a single
system to provide improved fault tolerance, load balancing, and failover
capability
Is d not an answer due to it being the same as load balancing? Round robin is a process used for network communication and operating system load balancing.

comments.content: round robin by itself is a generic algorithm
I'm going to assume its not the answer due combining different IP address into one single domain name and this talks about systems, not techniques.
Never even heard of round robin lol

questions.question_text: Which of the following allow for higher fault tolerance, availability, and performance across multiple systems? (Choose two.)

discussion.content: APPIPA doesn't require physical connectivity. It is a locally created address for when Windows can't reach a DHCP server for whatever reason.

This question is flawed in that you won't have a default gateway address when there is an APIPA address issued. No DHCP server, no routable IP address, no default gateway. I think C is the correct answer in that both parts of the answer would keep you from connecting to the DHCP server and not receiving a response to the DHCP Discover message.
What eliminates B from being the answer?
In my opinion, the correct answer should be A

comments.content: Being condescending does not help anyone.

discussion.content: Does the DNS server effect anything?
If the host didn't have physical connectivity how would it get the APIPA ?

comments.content: It might have a physical connectivity, but is on the wrong VLAN (The one with no DHCP server available)

choices.C: Verify the host has physical connectivity and is on the correct VLAN.
choices.D: Configure the DNS address in the DHCP scope to a 10.10.5.0/24 address.
choices.A: Change the IP scope on the DHCP server to a public IP address range.
choices.B: Perform a traceroute command to identify the router that is not functioning.

questions.question_text:
A technician is investigating an issue related to a single host that is unable to access the Internet. The technician records the following information: Host IP
169.254.1.10. The network IP address range on the DHCP server is 10.10.5.2-10.10.5.250 with a default gateway 10.10.5.1 and a DNS of 8.8.8.8. Which of the following should the technician perform to troubleshoot the issue?
A network administrator wants to reduce the amount of time each user takes to log in to different systems in the network. Which of the following would reduce the time spent authenticating?

discussion.content: I was gonna say Kerberos until I saw SSO . Kerberos uses SSO.
